items.title: Expected input range [0,1] or [-1,1] for TensorFlow Hub's image modules
items.body:
I have a question regarding image classification and using tranfer learning with MobileNetV2 and others (e.g. Inception).

[Here](https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/images/transfer_learning_with_hub) in the official tutorial by Google TensorFlow it says:
"All of TensorFlow Hub's image modules expect float inputs in the [0, 1] range."

In the [MobileNet](https://tfhub.dev/google/tf2-preview/mobilenet_v2/feature_vector/4) documentation it says:
"The input images are expected to have color values in the range [0,1], following the common image input conventions."

[Here](https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/images/transfer_learning) in the official tutorial by Google TensorFlow it says:
"Resize the images to a fixed input size, and rescale the input channels to a range of [-1,1]"

and indeed it is scaled to a range of [-1,1] and not [0,1]:
`image = (image/127.5) - 1`

Later on MobileNetv2 is used:
Create the base model from the pre-trained model MobileNet V2
```
base_model = tf.keras.applications.MobileNetV2(input_shape=IMG_SHAPE,
                                               include_top=False,
                                               weights='imagenet')
```
but I thought it needs [0,1] and not [-1,1]?

Now this is a contradiction in my eyes or I do not understand it.

What is right and what is wrong here? When do I have to rescale to [0,1] and when use [-1,1]? I thought as it said in the other sources all pretrained models from the tf hub use a common standard, [0,1], however, now I see in this official Google tutorial that rescaling is done to [-1,1]. I don't get this.

items.title: How does pre-trained ELMo produce embeddings for characters of different languages? (out-of-vocabulary alphabets)
items.body:
Here's the code from my notebook:

```python
%tensorflow_version 1.x
import tensorflow as tf
import tensorflow_hub as hub

elmo = hub.Module("https://tfhub.dev/google/elmo/2", trainable=True)
tf.logging.set_verbosity(tf.logging.ERROR)

def elmo_vectors(x):
    embeddings = elmo(x, signature="default", as_dict=True)["elmo"]
    with tf.Session() as sess:
        sess.run(tf.global_variables_initializer())
        sess.run(tf.tables_initializer())
        return sess.run(embeddings)
```

Output for non-English language: (Hindi in this example)

```python
words = ['गोकुल']
v = elmo_vectors(words)
print(v.shape) # (1,1,1024)
print(v[0][0])
# Output: [ 0.3731584   0.5700774  -0.48072845 ... -0.1241736   0.5961436 -0.6986947 ]
```

The [documentation of the pre-trained ELMo on Tensorflow Hub](https://tfhub.dev/google/elmo/2) shows that it was trained only on the English language.  
That is, the dataset from 1 billion word benchmark is based on monolingual English data. ([Source](https://opensource.google/projects/lm-benchmark))

So, how/why am I getting embeddings for non-English vocabulary words from ELMo using the TF Hub model?
Please explain.

items.title: How to extract a graph_def from TFHub saved_model (e.g. mobilenet_v2/feature_vector)

labels.name: hub
labels.description: For all issues related to tf hub library and tf hub tutorials or examples posted by hub team

items.body:
There are several TFHub models, in saved_model format,  that would be useful to convert into a graph_def using standard TF2 API.

For example, the model here: https://tfhub.dev/google/tf2-preview/mobilenet_v2/feature_vector/4

The snippet below should be able to extract out concrete function into a graph_def, convert it into a graph, and then print out all the node names. However, it looks tricky to get extract out the concrete function (because there is no signature of `serving_default` in the `serve` tag).

What's the best way to get the graph_def from this saved_model?

```python
import tensorflow as tf
from tensorflow.python.framework.convert_to_constants import convert_variables_to_constants_v2

model_path = r'd:\models_tfhub\tf2-preview_mobilenet_v2_feature_vector'

imported = tf.saved_model.load(model_path, tags=[['serve']])  # pylint: disable=no-value-for-parameter
concrete_func = imported.signatures['serving_default']
#concrete_func = imported.signatures['__saved_model_init_op']
frozen_func = convert_variables_to_constants_v2(concrete_func, lower_control_flow=False)
graph_def = frozen_func.graph.as_graph_def(add_shapes=True)
with tf.Graph().as_default() as inferred_graph:
    tf.import_graph_def(graph_def, name="")

nodes = inferred_graph.get_operations()
for n in nodes:
    print (n.name)
```

items.title: clarification with TF datasets: more efficient to vectorize with unbatching (batch -> map -> unbatch) or just map?
items.body:
Hi, 

First time reporting an issue on Github - as far as I can tell this is also the place to report or request anything related to the official documentation and guides as well, which is what this is about. (Apologies if this is not the case!)

I have seen in several (non-official) code examples posted online that people apply vectorized mapping in the following way using the dataset API: batch -> map -> unbatch. The relevant official guides at https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/data and https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/data_performance don't address this (either encourage or discourage). I originally implemented this myself, thinking that there must be a reason so many other people were doing it, but I've since found that in at least some cases this is very inefficient (at least in the cases I tested, it increased the time to apply the overall transformation by 150% over just applying map without adding batch/unbatch).

I posted on stackoverflow asking about this at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61876941/tensorflow-datasets-more-efficient-to-vectorize-with-unbatching-batch-map but haven't received a response. If there is a good rule of thumb (other than testing every transformation, data type, batch size, hardware, etc. on a case-by-case basis) is it possible to add it to the documentation, or at least warn that it might cause a serious slowdown? I could see there being cases where this method does increase efficiency, but then again, maybe not.

Thanks.

I am interested to use USE for text Classification, and I am using this code that gets the embedding as a trainable layer in my ML model:

items.title: Applying stylization on batches causes problems
items.body:
Hi. 

I am currently using [the stylization module of TF-Hub](https://tfhub.dev/google/magenta/arbitrary-image-stylization-v1-256/2) for a set of experiments where I am applying stylization at random on a set of images. Consider that as a data augmentation operation. 

After applying stylization, the images are coming out as the following: 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22957388/82208496-40514c00-9929-11ea-9d7c-5544e628c27a.png)

I am using the Cats-vs.-Dogs dataset and I am loading it using the following code listing:
```python
train_ds, validation_ds = tfds.load(
    'cats_vs_dogs',
    split=['train[:85%]', 'train[85%:]'],
    as_supervised=True
)
```

After this, I am creating a utility function to apply the stylization module to a given image and I am mapping that utility like so - 

```python
train_ds = (
    train_ds
    .map(preprocess_image, num_parallel_calls=AUTO)
    .shuffle(1024)
    .map(apply_random_stylization, num_parallel_calls=AUTO)
    .batch(BATCH_SIZE)
    .prefetch(AUTO)
)
```
`apply_random_stylization` is defined as - 

```python
def apply_random_stylization(image, label):
    image = random_apply(stylize_image, image, p=0.8)
    return (image, label)

def random_apply(func, x, p):
        return tf.cond(
          tf.less(tf.random.uniform([], minval=0, maxval=1, dtype=tf.float32),
                  tf.cast(p, tf.float32)),
          lambda: func(x),
          lambda: x)
        
def stylize_image(image):
    stylized_image = HUB_MODULE(tf.expand_dims(image, 0), tf.constant(STYLE_IMG))[0]
    stylized_image = tf.squeeze(stylized_image)
    return tf.clip_by_value(stylized_image, 0., 1.)
```

Here's the [Colab Gist](https://colab.research.google.com/gist/sayakpaul/2c5dbcce0ec659c9b9e5be0149304c35/scratchpad.ipynb) that reproduces this issue. 

Any help would be appreciated. Thanks!

I did read the documentation on tensorflow hub methods to see if I could get access but the documentation spelling out what is available seems lite on details:
https://www.tensorflow.org/hub/api_docs/python/hub/load

> .variables: a list of variables from the loaded object;
.signatures: a dict of TF2 ConcreteFunctions, keyed by signature names, that take tensor kwargs and return a tensor dict. However, the information imported by hub.Module into the collections of a tf.Graph is lost (e.g., regularization losses and update ops).

Any clarity on how to do this would be appreciated.

-Neil

**Describe the current behavior**

```
# model is from: https://tfhub.dev/tensorflow/bert_en_cased_L-12_H-768_A-12/1

saved_model_dir = "path/to/bert_en_cased_L-12_H-768_A-12/1"
loaded_model = tf.saved_model.load(saved_model_dir)

prediction = concrete_func(**inputs)
```

As an user, I'm expecting output names to be `["Identity", "Identity_1"]` as shown:

Expecting the prediction output has same name as `concrete_func.outputs`.

items.title: Loading EfficientNet-Lite4 or EfficientNet-Lite2 Feature Vectors as KerasLayer() fails from tfhub.dev
items.body:
## Problem Description
Both EfficientNet-Lite4 and EfficientNet-Lite2 feature-vector modules fail to download correctly when attempting to create a feature layer using `tensorflow_hub.KerasLayer()` with the tfhub.dev URLs. 

The temporary directory is created, but none of the files are downloaded/saved.

Error only occurs for EfficientNet-Lite2 and EfficientNet-Lite4 versions.  Additional testing indicates that EfficientNet-Lite0, EfficientNet-Lite1, and EfficientNet-Lite3 work properly.

Issue first logged 2020-05-03.  
Was previously working fine as of 2020-04-30

## System Info:

**OS**: Windows 10
**Python**: 3.7.7
**Tensorflow**: 2.1.0
**Tensorflow-Hub**: 0.8.0

## Code Snippet:

```python
import tensorflow_hub as hub
import tensorflow as tf

# EfficientNet-Lite4
MODULE_HANDLE = "https://tfhub.dev/tensorflow/efficientnet/lite4/feature-vector/2"
EN4_feature_layer = hub.KerasLayer(MODULE_HANDLE)

# EfficientNet-Lite2
MODULE_HANDLE = "https://tfhub.dev/tensorflow/efficientnet/lite2/feature-vector/2"
EN2_feature_layer = hub.KerasLayer(MODULE_HANDLE)
```

### Error

Manually download and extract the feature vector modules for EfficientNet-Lite4 or EfficientNet-Lite2 from tfhub.dev, then create the `KerasLayer` using the local path instead of the URL.

items.title: Using large vocabulary in SentencePiece Library to get sentence embeddings using USE Lite model degrades the embeddings
items.body:
I am currently working on using the Universal Sentence Encoder Lite model for getting text embeddings for our corpus to find similar items. The [documentations ](https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder-lite/2) says to process the sentences using the [SentencePiece Library](https://github.com/google/sentencepiece) before passing them to the model. 

The default model of the SentencePiece library has a vocabulary size of 8K. Using this I am able to get good results. I then tried to use a larger vocabulary of size 30K from SentencePiece to see if the quality improves. I found out that the quality of the embeddings degrades.  

I used annoy library to build the index of the embedding vectors to get the K nearest matching items. The results I got with the embeddings from the larger vocabulary is giving very bad results (that have no significance to the input text).

Wanted to know if the USE Lite model is specifically trained on SentencePiece 8k vocabulary.

Thank you.

```python
import tensorflow as tf
```

items.title: Explanation to the `bert_model/pooler_transform/kernel`
items.body:
If we load the bert model by:
```
import tensorflow_hub as hub
bert_layer = hub.KerasLayer("https://tfhub.dev/tensorflow/bert_en_uncased_L-12_H-768_A-12/1",
                            trainable=True)
```
Then if we print out all inside components by using:
```
for variable in bert_layer.variables:
    print(variable.name, variable.trainable)
```
We find the last three objects are:
```
bert_model/pooler_transform/kernel:0 True
bert_model/pooler_transform/bias:0 True
Variable:0 False
```
As far as I know, the pooler layer with `tanh` activation function should apply to only `[cls]` token; however, it seems that it is applied to the whole sequence, if we call:
`pooled_output, sequence_output = bert_layer([input_word_ids, input_mask, segment_ids])`

Is this the correct way?  Thanks.

items.title: How to load keras model which has Universal Sentence Encoder embedding layer once then use it for prediction?
items.body:
I'm a newbie in tensorflow. Currently I'm creating a model for classification. My code saved keras model as h5 file successfully, now I'm trying to use this model for predict any input text's label from REST API.

This is my current code and it works

def universal_embedding(x):
  embed = hub.Module(url)
  return embed(tf.squeeze(tf.cast(x, tf.string), axis=[1]), signature="default", as_dict=True)["default"]


def create_model():
  input_text = layers.Input(shape=(1,), dtype=tf.string)
  embedding = layers.Lambda(universal_embedding, output_shape=(512,))(input_text)
  dense = layers.Dense(256, activation='relu')(embedding)
  pred = layers.Dense(4, activation='softmax')(dense)

  model = Model(inputs=[input_text], outputs=pred)
  model.compile(loss='categorical_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])
  model.summary()

  return model

@app.route("/predictLabel", methods=['GET', 'POST'])
@cross_origin()
def predict_label():
  model = create_model()

  request_data = json.loads(request.data)
  text = request_data['text']

  request_list = [text]

  request_list = np.array(request_list, dtype=object)[:, np.newaxis]

  with tf.compat.v1.Session() as session:
     K.set_session(session)
     session.run([tf.compat.v1.global_variables_initializer(), tf.compat.v1.tables_initializer()])
     model.load_weights('./model.h5')
     predicts = model.predict(request_list, batch_size=32)


As you can see, every a new request comes, the model needs to load again, so how can I move the loading model part outside the function so the application loads it when starting once? I know we need to deal with tensorflow session and graph to do this but not sure how to implement it. Thank you very much.

milestone.title: Community Module Requests
milestone.description:
The TensorFlow Hub team generates only a small fraction of the assets that are available on tfhub.dev. We rely primarily on other internal Alphabet teams, corporate and academic research institutions, and ML enthusiasts to produce modules. As a result, we can't guarantee that we can fulfill community requests for specific assets, and we can't provide time estimates for new asset availability.

This milestone contains all open requests for modules requested by the community -- if you'd like to contribute, please see our contribution documentation here: https://github.com/tensorflow/hub/tree/master/tfhub_dev

labels.description: This is a request for a new module. Not a bug or issue with the hub library.

milestone.title: Community Module Requests
milestone.description:
The TensorFlow Hub team generates only a small fraction of the assets that are available on tfhub.dev. We rely primarily on other internal Alphabet teams, corporate and academic research institutions, and ML enthusiasts to produce modules. As a result, we can't guarantee that we can fulfill community requests for specific assets, and we can't provide time estimates for new asset availability.

This milestone contains all open requests for modules requested by the community -- if you'd like to contribute, please see our contribution documentation here: https://github.com/tensorflow/hub/tree/master/tfhub_dev

items.title: make_image_classifier: write summary/logs for TensorBoard
items.body:
`make_image_classifier` should have an option to write a summary/logs to be visualized by TensorBoard.

/edit:

**System information**
- TensorFlow version (you are using): 2.1, and `tensorflow-hub[make_image_classifier]~=0.6`
- Are you willing to contribute it (Yes/No): No


**Describe the feature and the current behavior/state.**
The current version of `make_image_classifier` does not write logs/summaries which can be used to feed TensorBoard.

A command line option like `--summaries_dir /tmp/retrain_logs` should write those after completing the training. For a reference, see [https://github.com/tensorflow/hub/blob/v0.7.0/examples/image_retraining/retrain.py#L1199].

**Will this change the current api? How?**
No

**Who will benefit with this feature?**
Probably Tensorflow beginners, for which the `make_image_classifier` seems to be targeted.

**Any Other info.**

```
Python version: Python 3.7.6 
tensorflow-hub==0.7.0
```

```
for i, message_embedding in enumerate(np.array(message_embeddings).tolist()):
  print("Message: {}".format(messages[i]))
  print("Embedding size: {}".format(len(message_embedding)))
  message_embedding_snippet = ", ".join(
      (str(x) for x in message_embedding[:3]))
  print("Embedding: [{}, ...]\n".format(message_embedding_snippet))
```

```
TypeError: Tensor objects are only iterable when eager execution is enabled. To iterate over this tensor use tf.map_fn.
```

Adding the eager execution seemed to solve the problem:

```
tf.compat.v1.enable_eager_execution()
```

items.title: Regarding GSOC 2020

labels.name: hub
labels.description: For all issues related to tf hub library and tf hub tutorials or examples posted by hub team

items.body:
Hello everyone,
I am interested in applying with TF Hub for GSOC 2020.
Are there any specific tasks to accomplish before writing the proposal for the same?

items.title: Unable to save model that contains a tf hub module

labels.name: hub
labels.description: For all issues related to tf hub library and tf hub tutorials or examples posted by hub team

items.body:
Hello, I am bumping into issues when trying to save a model that contains a TF Hub Module. Here is an examples that I would expect to work, but instead raises an exception:

```python
import tensorflow as tf
import tensorflow_hub as hub

from tensorflow.keras.models import Model
from tensorflow.keras import Input
from tensorflow.keras.layers import LSTM, Dense, Lambda

sess = tf.compat.v1.Session()
tf.compat.v1.keras.backend.set_session(sess)
tf.compat.v1.disable_eager_execution()

# random number, not important for this example
n_tags = 17
max_len = 50
batch_size = 32

elmo_model = hub.Module("https://tfhub.dev/google/elmo/2", trainable=True)

def ElmoEmbedding(x):
    return elmo_model(inputs={"tokens": tf.squeeze(tf.cast(x, tf.string)),
                              "sequence_len": tf.constant(
                                  batch_size * [max_len])
                              },
                      signature="tokens",
                      as_dict=True)["elmo"]


input_text = Input(shape=(max_len,), dtype=tf.string)
embedding = Lambda(ElmoEmbedding, output_shape=(max_len, 1024))(input_text)
x = LSTM(units=512, return_sequences=True, recurrent_dropout=0.2,
                       dropout=0.2)(embedding)
out = Dense(n_tags, activation="softmax")(x)

model = Model(input_text, out)
model.compile(optimizer="adam", loss="sparse_categorical_crossentropy")

model.save("saved_model")
```

I would expect for the model to be saved under the directory `saved_model`, but instead the following error is raised: `"tensorflow_hub/module.py", line 245, in __call__: RuntimeError: Module must be applied in the graph it was instantiated for.`

So, for some reason, the condition `self._graph is not tf_v1.get_default_graph()` fails.

My understanding (from https://www.tensorflow.org/hub/tf2_saved_model) is that TF Hub models are all `SavedModels`, so I don't understand why saving a model that encapsulates a TF Hub model does not work. I am sure I am missing something. It would be great if someone could shed some light on this, as this is super critical for what we are trying to accomplish. Thanks!

---

Current Environment:

- Python v3.6.9
- tensorflow==2.1.0
- tensorflow-hub==0.7.0

items.title: Missing Doc in signatures' __init__ API.
items.body:
The issue can be reproduced on CoLab: https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1V--H9ZDFsc1QEfsel8oNSlg_Ofr3azhh

------------------------------------

The model is `https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder-qa/1` and `https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder-qa/2`. I load the models with `hub.load()`: 

```
model1 = hub.load(r"https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder-qa/1")
model2 = hub.load(r"https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder-qa/2")
```

Choose a signature: `question_encoder`. Then see an functional API in V1 model: 

```
print(model1.signatures["question_encoder"].__init__.__doc__)
print(inspect.signature(model1.signatures["question_encoder"].__init__))
## None
## (fn_graph, variable_holder, attrs=None, signature=None)
```

...Then see the V2 model: 

```
print(model2.signatures["question_encoder"].__init__.__doc__)
print(inspect.signature(model2.signatures["question_encoder"].__init__))
## None
## (concrete_function)
```

... From the above cells, we can find that the argument list is different, but the documentation is still missing. It may be an issue and in my humble opinion, there should be some explanatory doc.

items.title: Error when executed the code specified in the documentation of USE-Multilingual-qa-3
items.body:
In [USE-Multilingual-qa-V2](https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder-multilingual-qa/2), it is mentioned that 

> Warning: An updated version of this module is available at https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder-multilingual-qa/3 .

But when executed the code specified in the [USE-Multilingual-V3](https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder-multilingual-qa/3), it is resulting in the below mentioned error,

> TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for *: 'dict' and 'dict'

Reproducible code is mentioned below:

```
!pip install tensorflow==2.1
!pip install "tensorflow_hub>=0.6.0"
!pip3 install tensorflow_text>=2.0.0rc0

import tensorflow as tf
import tensorflow_hub as hub
import numpy as np
import tensorflow_text

questions = ["What is your age?"]
responses = ["I am 20 years old.", "good morning"]
response_contexts = ["I will be 21 next year.", "great day."]

module = hub.load('https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder-multilingual-qa/3')

question_embeddings = module.signatures['question_encoder'](
            tf.constant(questions))
response_embeddings = module.signatures['response_encoder'](
        input=tf.constant(responses),
        context=tf.constant(response_contexts))

np.inner(question_embeddings, response_embeddings)
```

Please find the attached [Github Gist](https://colab.sandbox.google.com/gist/rmothukuru/7540269a3a4dfac2491c1e0f002f379b/use_qa_3_error.ipynb#scrollTo=wqlBss1AKtwU) as well.

items.title: Universal Sentence Encoder v2 vs. v4

labels.name: type:performance

I am comparing the performance of v2 and v4. I understand that v4's main difference is to upgrade to tensorflow 2.0. However, I can see that v4 performance has been deteriorating comparing to v2. Are there any reasons for that? Or the model is meant to kept this way?
I was using a cosine similarity to identify the most similar terms in 2 lists. V2 yields a much better results than V4. I tested the 2 models on various examples and V2 results is consistently better than V4.

Has there been a research for evaluating the performance of V4?

For example: For the phase "I have a rash on my skin", and run the 2 models on the same list. V2 shows an appropriate results while V4 doesnt. 
- V2 will output the top match as "dermatologist" with cosine similarity = 0.6707976305

- V4 will output the top match as "mental health" cosine similarity = 0.0761242328; and "dermatologist" cosine similarity is very low

items.title: Releasing MobileBERT as KerasLayer/Hub Module

labels.name: type:module request
labels.description: This is a request for a new module. Not a bug or issue with the hub library.

milestone.title: Community Module Requests
milestone.description:
The TensorFlow Hub team generates only a small fraction of the assets that are available on tfhub.dev. We rely primarily on other internal Alphabet teams, corporate and academic research institutions, and ML enthusiasts to produce modules. As a result, we can't guarantee that we can fulfill community requests for specific assets, and we can't provide time estimates for new asset availability.

This milestone contains all open requests for modules requested by the community -- if you'd like to contribute, please see our contribution documentation here: https://github.com/tensorflow/hub/tree/master/tfhub_dev

items.body:
Is there any plan on releasing [MobileBERT](https://tfhub.dev/tensorflow/mobilebert/1) as a KerasLayer or Hub Module? I'd like to compare the finetuning performance against other distillation methods for downstream tasks such as text classification.

I know the intent of the model is to be used in a mobile device, but without finetuning the best performance we can get out of it is limited. Thus, will a .h5 or .pb version of the model be made available along the .tflite? Otherwise, is there any plan to support conversion **from TFLite back to TFKeras** (this [thread](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59559289/is-there-any-way-to-convert-the-tflite-file-back-to-keash5) seems to tell me it is not currently possible)?

items.title: object detection notebook has decode error
items.body:
In this notebook: https://github.com/tensorflow/hub/blob/master/examples/colab/object_detection.ipynb

If you run it top to bottom, it currently hits an error on this cell:
`run_detector(detector, downloaded_image_path)`

The error reads: `'bytes' object has no attribute 'numpy'`

It's because draw_boxes() runs the following line:
`class_names[i].numpy().decode("ascii")`

which for some reason (maybe python2 compat???) calls `.numpy()` on the class names, which are coming back as bytestrings in python3. propose removing the `.numpy()` call and keeping `.decode("ascii")`. Seems to work in py2 and py3 with this change.

```
InternalError: 2 root error(s) found.

	 [[{{node sequential/keras_layer/StatefulPartitionedCall/StatefulPartitionedCall/StatefulPartitionedCall/EncoderTransformer/Transformer/PrepareForTransformer/dense/MatMul}}]]

  (1) Internal:  Blas GEMM launch failed : a.shape=(17, 320), b.shape=(320, 512), m=17, n=512, k=320

distributed_function -> distributed_function
```

When trying to train USE 5 on GPU, here is the minimal code:

```python
import tensorflow as tf
import tensorflow_hub as hub

# MODEL = "https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder/4"
MODEL = "https://tfhub.dev/google/universal-sentence-encoder-large/5"
DIM = 512
IS_TRAINABLE = False #Works if False

train_data = ["Hello world", "I'll fix it", "Function instantiation has undefined input shape"]
train_labels = [0, 0, 1]

hub_layer = hub.KerasLayer(MODEL, output_shape=[DIM], input_shape=[], trainable=IS_TRAINABLE, dtype=tf.string)

model = tf.keras.Sequential()
model.add(hub_layer)
model.add(tf.keras.layers.Dense(1))

model.compile(optimizer="adam", loss="binary_crossentropy")
model.fit(train_data, train_labels)
```

I can already confirm that GPU is not running out of memory, the model only takes up 1.5GB/16GB 

Any help would be appreciated? I've found similar issues, but solutions such as:

```python
try: 
    tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True) 
    assert tf.config.experimental.get_memory_growth(physical_devices[0]) 
except: 
  # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized. 
    pass  
```

```
import tensorflow as tf
from tensorflow.keras.layers import Dense, Concatenate, RepeatVector, Activation, Dot, Bidirectional, Flatten, Embedding, Input, SpatialDropout1D, LSTM, Dropout, Lambda, Conv2D, Conv1D, Attention, AdditiveAttention, GlobalAveragePooling1D, TimeDistributed, AveragePooling1D
from tensorflow.keras.models import Model
from tensorflow.keras.backend import backend
import tensorflow_hub as hub
from tensorflow.keras.datasets import imdb
from tensorflow.keras.preprocessing.sequence import pad_sequences
import numpy as np
import tensorflow_datasets as tfds

def cnn_classifier():
    # Encode each timestep
    # embedding = Embedding(10000, 300, trainable=True)(input)

    embedding = "https://tfhub.dev/google/tf2-preview/gnews-swivel-20dim/1"
    input = Input(shape=(None,), name="Input")
    hub_layer = hub.KerasLayer(embedding, trainable=True)(input)
    cnn = Conv1D(64,3, padding="same", activation="relu")(hub_layer)
    cnn = Conv1D(32, 3, padding="same", activation="relu")(cnn)
    cnn = Conv1D(16, 3, padding="same", activation="relu")(cnn)
    cnn = Flatten()(cnn)
    output = Dense(1, activation="sigmoid")(cnn)

    model = Model(input, output)
    model.compile(loss="binary_crossentropy",
                  optimizer="adam",
                  metrics=["accuracy"])
    model.summary()
    return model

model = cnn_classifier()

train_validation_split = tfds.Split.TRAIN.subsplit([8, 2])

(train_data, validation_data), test_data = tfds.load(
    name="imdb_reviews",
    split=(train_validation_split, tfds.Split.TEST),

#test_data = pad_sequences(test_data, maxlen=1100, dtype='int32', padding='post', truncating='post', value=0.0)

model.fit(train_data.shuffle(25000).batch(512),
                    epochs=20,
                    validation_data=validation_data.batch(512),
                    verbose=10)
```

items.title: Cannot save keras model based on hub module

labels.name: hub
labels.description: For all issues related to tf hub library and tf hub tutorials or examples posted by hub team

items.body:
Hi,

I am trying to follow the fine-tuning tutorial for my own dataset, and I have built a model as follows:
```
module = hub.Module(tuning_model_url, trainable=True, name='efficientnet_b1')
#... some code for getting module expected image size and inputs

model = tf.keras.Sequential([
    hub.KerasLayer(module, trainable=False),
    tf.keras.layers.Dropout(0.2),
    tf.keras.layers.Dense(100, activation='relu', kernel_regularizer=tf.keras.regularizers.l2(0.001)),
    tf.keras.layers.Dropout(0.2),
    tf.keras.layers.Dense(train_data.num_classes, activation='softmax', 
                          kernel_regularizer=tf.keras.regularizers.l2(0.0001)),
])

model.build(input_shape=(None, img_size[0], img_size[1], 3)) # Saver warn

model.compile(optimizer='rmsprop', 
              loss=tf.keras.losses.CategoricalCrossentropy(from_logits=True, label_smoothing=0.1),
              metrics=['accuracy'])
```


### Saving before training

If I don't train the model, and I try to save it directly, I get:

- `model.save('../models/keras_effnet_b1')`

```
WARNING:tensorflow:Skipping full serialization of Keras model <tensorflow.python.keras.engine.sequential.Sequential object at 0x7f8c1c107e50>, because its inputs are not defined.

ValueError: Model <tensorflow.python.keras.engine.sequential.Sequential object at 0x7f8c1c107e50> cannot be saved because the input shapes have not been set. Usually, input shapes are automatically determined from calling .fit() or .predict(). To manually set the shapes, call model._set_inputs(inputs).
```


- `tf.saved_model.save(model, '../models/effnet_b1_1')`

```
WARNING:tensorflow:Skipping full serialization of Keras model <tensorflow.python.keras.engine.sequential.Sequential object at 0x7f8c1c107e50>, because its inputs are not defined.

INFO:tensorflow:Assets written to: ../models/effnet_b1_1/assets
```

So, it appears the the `tf` version works, there are some files on disk, though I'm not 100% sure of their content due to the warning.

### Saving after training

If I run `model.fit(...)`, then each of the above methods gives the same error:
```
RuntimeError: Module must be applied in the graph it was instantiated for.
```


Also, when calling `model.build` in the line marked with `# Saver warn`, I get the following warning: `INFO:tensorflow:Saver not created because there are no variables in the graph to restore`. What is interesting is that I also get this warning when calling `model.fit(...)` afterwards, which suggests that the model / session / graph is reinitialised, hence probably the error about the module not belonging to the graph.

### Solution ?

How can I overcome the error `Module must be applied in the graph it was instantiated for.` ?
